title: Privacy Boundary Clarification for External Data Sources
normative_intent: External data sources must declare their privacy classification before integration. The system will not process data whose privacy status is unknown. This motion establishes that privacy boundaries are explicit, not inferred, and that the system's default posture toward unclassified data is refusal rather than assumption.
constraints: Must not require disclosure of source identity to achieve classification
Must not create implicit consent through continued use
Must not block emergency response scenarios where immediate action is required
Must not impose classification burden on data subjects rather than data controllers
Must not conflate privacy classification with security classification
success_criteria: All external data sources have explicit privacy classification within 90 days of motion ratification
No unclassified data enters the processing pipeline after implementation deadline
Emergency override path exists with full audit trail for time-critical scenarios
Classification can be verified by any authorized party without accessing the data itself
Rejection of unclassified data is logged with sufficient detail for source remediation
what_this_motion_does_not_cover: Specific technical controls or encryption standards
Timeline for compliance beyond the 90-day window
Penalty or consequence for non-compliance by sources
Definition of what constitutes 'emergency response scenarios'
Integration with existing data governance frameworks

deliberation.deliberation_summary: Motion received broad support during deliberation. Duke Valefor noted alignment with ongoing data governance program. Earl Glasya raised concern about emergency override definition being left to implementation; sponsor King Bael clarified this is intentional to preserve Executive flexibility on HOW. No amendments proposed.
